repnme.cdata!: Sri Lanka - Major Irrigation Rehabiltation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Major Irrigation
            Rehabilitation Project for Sri Lanka was marginally
            satisfactory. The project achieved most of its objectives,
            its impact on institutional development was modest,
            sustainability is uncertain at this time, and both the Bank
            and Borrower performed satisfactorily. Several lessons can
            be learned from this project. First, adequate long term
            measures, both institutional and financial, should be built
            into the design of projects. Second, more attention needs to
            be given to raising both general awareness and technical
            capability of lower level technicians in the area of water
            management. Third, more attention should be given to
            agricultural extension services and marketing. Fourth, O
            & M of irrigation systems cannot be carried out by
            farmers alone. It requires skilled inputs from technical
            personnel as well as adequate funding. Fifth, it is
            necessary to improve farmers' incomes through crop
            diversification in the yala season where possible. Lastly,
            farmer organizations undertaking construction activities is
            a good concept. However, they should be protected against
            major price fluctuations in materials to enable them to
            carry out work without delay.

display_title.display_title:
Sri Lanka - Major Irrigation
            Rehabilitation Project : Credit 1537 - Credit Agreement - Conformed

repnme.cdata!: Sri Lanka - Major Irrigation Rehabilitation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Major Irrigation Rehabilitation
            Project seeks to increase agricultural production on land
            commanded by seven selected major irrigation systems.  The
            project aims to accomplish this by:  (a) rehabilitating
            seven existing irrigation systems serving a total area of
            about 46,000 hectares; and (b) introducing an integrated
            management program to ensure proper operation and
            maintenance of the systems and distribution of irrigation
            supplies.  It also intends to achieve increased agricultural
            production through:  (c) strengthening support services
            provided by various government agencies; and (d) making
            provision for monitoring and evaluation of project execution
            and performance.

docna.cdata!: Sri Lanka - Major Irrigation Rehabilitation Project
